solutionsHub.headline: Warehouse Execution Solutions for Real Operational Scenarios
solutionsHub.subline: LogisQ-WES adapts to different warehouse types, automation levels, and modernization contexts — without changing execution semantics across different warehouse scenarios.

cards.title: Manual Warehouses
cards.teaser: Structured execution, clear priorities, and predictable processes — without automation overhead.

cards.title: Automated Warehouses
cards.teaser: Deterministic execution across conveyors, shuttles, cranes, and robots.

cards.title: Distribution Centers
cards.teaser: High throughput, strict sequencing, and stable execution for complex distribution operations.

cards.title: E-Commerce Fulfillment
cards.teaser: Fast order processing, dynamic priorities, and controlled execution under peak load.

cards.title: Brownfield Modernization
cards.teaser: Modernize step by step — without risky 'big bang' replacements or execution breaks.

cards.title: Greenfield Implementation
cards.teaser: Build execution-ready warehouses from day one — without late reinterpretation during go-live.

cards.title: Hazardous Goods Warehousing
cards.teaser: Controlled execution, strict process boundaries, and auditable handling flows.

cards.title: AutoStore Integration
cards.teaser: Orders flow through AutoStore cubes with the same execution consistency as any other zone.

cards.title: Sorting & High-Throughput Systems
cards.teaser: Deterministic sequencing and execution for peak-load material flow systems.

cards.title: Mixed Automation Environments
cards.teaser: Unified execution across conveyors, shuttles, AMRs, AGVs, and manual zones.

meta.title: Warehouse Execution for Manual Warehouses | BSS LogisQ
meta.description: Structured execution and clear priorities for non-automated warehouse operations.

requirements.title: What manual warehouses require
items: Clear task priorities for warehouse operators
Predictable process flows without system complexity

support.title: How LogisQ-WES supports this scenario
support.text: LogisQ-WES provides a structured execution layer that defines and enforces priorities without requiring automation. Operators receive clear, sequenced tasks while management gains visibility into execution flow.

semantics.title: Why execution semantics remain stable
semantics.text: Process definitions don't change between planning and operation. What you design is what gets executed — regardless of operator or shift.

meta.title: Warehouse Execution for E-Commerce Fulfillment | BSS LogisQ
meta.description: Fast order processing and dynamic priorities for peak-load fulfillment.

requirements.title: What e-commerce fulfillment requires
items: Fast reaction to incoming order waves
Seamless integration of returns and picking

challenges.title: Typical execution challenges
items: Chaotic execution when priorities shift rapidly
Inflexible logic that can't adapt to wave peaks

support.title: How LogisQ-WES supports this scenario
support.text: LogisQ-WES handles massive event volumes with a deterministic execution model. It ensures that fulfillment processes stay on track even when volumes spike, by maintaining a strict priority queue that respects SLAs.

semantics.title: Why execution semantics remain stable
semantics.text: The logic for order fulfillment is defined at the semantic level. Spikes in volume increase throughput but don't change how the system fundamentally executes tasks.

meta.title: Brownfield Modernization Solutions | BSS LogisQ
meta.description: Modernize legacy warehouses step-by-step without execution breaks.

hero.title: Brownfield Modernization
hero.subtitle: Modernize without bringing operations to a halt

requirements.title: What legacy modernization requires
items: Coexistence of old and new systems
Unified visibility across disparate hardware generations

challenges.title: Typical execution challenges
items: Integration gaps between legacy PLC and modern WMS
Inconsistent data models across old equipment

support.title: How LogisQ-WES supports this scenario
support.text: Our Communication Hub acts as a semantic bridge, allowing you to wrap legacy hardware in modern execution semantics. You can modernize one aisle or zone at a time without breaking the overall warehouse workflow.

semantics.title: Why execution semantics remain stable
semantics.text: LogisQ-WES decouples the physical hardware from the execution logic. Even if you replace an old conveyor with a modern shuttle, the *execution semantcs* (what happens to the goods) remains identical.

modularWesPage.subtitle: Bridge sales promise and technical reality
modularWesPage.intro: LogisQ-WES is an intralogistics software product composed of specialized modules connected via the CommunicationHUB.

comparison.desc: Why a specialized execution layer is necessary.

pillars.p1Desc: The central backbone that decouples systems.
pillars.p2Desc: Modules can be upgraded without breaking the system.
pillars.p3Desc: Integrates with existing hardware and software.

modularWesPage.techDesc: Dive deeper into the architecture that makes this possible.

digitalTwinPage.roadmapDesc: We are continuously expanding our simulation capabilities to support predictive maintenance and advanced scenario testing.

companyPage.title: A Strategic Joint Venture
companyPage.subtitle: Combining logistics heritage with software innovation.
companyPage.intro: LogisQ-WES is the result of a powerful partnership between BSS Bohnenberg (Intralogistics) and Macrix Technology Group (Software Engineering).

bss.title: BSS Bohnenberg
bss.desc: With over 30 years of experience as a general contractor for intralogistics, BSS understands the physical reality of the warehouse.

macrix.title: Macrix
macrix.desc: The creators of the ArconQ platform. Macrix brings 25 years of high-performance software engineering to the industrial sector.

companyPage.footer: Together, we deliver a system that is both physically realistic and architecturally superior.

hero.description: No reinterpretation between planning and operation. What you design is what gets executed.
hero.anchor: Coordinates warehouse execution across people, automation, and systems in real time.

problem.title: Why warehouse projects slip late — not early
problem.p1: Decisions made during planning are reinterpreted during implementation
problem.p2: Commissioning turns into a discovery phase instead of a validation step
problem.p3: Go-live dates move, even though "everything was already defined"
problem.bridge: Most delays are not caused by missing features, but by late reinterpretation of already-made decisions.

difference.title: Designed to run as planned
difference.p1: Decisions are defined once and remain consistent across the project
difference.p2: Planning, execution, and operation follow the same semantic model
difference.p3: No hidden behavior emerges during commissioning
difference.support: Execution is not improvised at the end — it is structurally prepared from the beginning.

operational.title: What LogisQ-WES does in daily operation
operational.intro: The **PER module** orchestrates warehouse execution by coordinating priorities, resources, and real-time task flow across manual and automated operations.
operational.block1Desc: Controls the order and timing of warehouse tasks based on defined rules and current conditions.
operational.block2Desc: Aligns people, automation, and fleets within a single execution flow.
operational.block3Desc: Connects warehouse management decisions with shop-floor execution without semantic breaks.

playbooks.title: Project Playbooks
playbooks.narrative: **PER** handles priority and execution sequencing ensuring optimal flow.

productStructureLight.title: One product. Clear responsibilities.
productStructureLight.wms: WMS defines business decisions, priorities, and warehouse logic.
productStructureLight.per: PER executes defined processes in a controlled and observable way.
productStructureLight.mfc: MFC translates execution requests into physical movements.
productStructureLight.hub: CommunicationHUB connects external systems and equipment without embedding logic.
productStructureLight.fleet: Fleet Management coordinates mobile robots and vehicles within the execution flow.

benefits.desc1: Projects go live faster because execution behavior is defined early and does not change late.
benefits.desc2: Upgrade or extend existing warehouses without rewriting execution logic.
benefits.desc3: Clear visibility into priorities, execution state, and dependencies during operation.
benefits.desc4: Automation hardware outlasts software cycles because execution semantics remain stable.
benefits.desc5: New technologies integrate without side effects because changes do not leak into execution behavior.

digitalTwinRepositioned.title: Design-time transparency (optional)
digitalTwinRepositioned.p1: Digital Twin technology supports understanding, alignment, and validation during design and planning.
digitalTwinRepositioned.p2: It improves communication and confidence — without replacing execution logic.

trust.title: Go deeper — or start a conversation

technologyPage.wesDefinition: A Warehouse Execution System (WES) coordinates real-time warehouse tasks across systems, people, and automation.

intro.title: Why LogisQ-WES works reliably in real warehouses
intro.bodyShort: Processes are executed as defined, not as reinterpreted later.
intro.body:
LogisQ-WES ensures that warehouse processes are executed **as defined**, not as reinterpreted later.

Its architecture removes semantic gaps between planning, execution, and operation.

boundaries.title: Clear responsibilities instead of blurred control
boundaries.intro: LogisQ-WES is a product composed of specialized modules. Each module has a **strict, non-overlapping responsibility**.
boundaries.wms: **WMS** defines business decisions, priorities, and warehouse logic
boundaries.per: **PER** executes defined processes in a controlled and observable way
boundaries.mfc: **MFC** translates execution requests into physical movements
boundaries.hub: **CommunicationHUB** connects external systems and equipment without embedding logic
boundaries.fleet: **Fleet Management** coordinates mobile vehicles within execution boundaries

execution.title: Workflow-first, deterministic execution
execution.intro: Execution in LogisQ-WES follows a **workflow-first model**:
execution.p3: Runtime behavior is deterministic and traceable

safety.title: Enforcement over trust
safety.intro: Execution is governed by explicit authorization and scope rules:
safety.p1: Every execution runs within a defined **ProcessScope**
safety.p2: Only authorized actions are allowed to execute

stack.title: A platform designed for controlled execution
stack.intro: LogisQ-WES runs on the **ArconQ Platform**, providing:
stack.list: Service orchestration, Event-driven communication, Observability, Controlled deployment
stack.bridge: On top of ArconQ, domain-specific modules implement warehouse execution.

integration.title: Event-driven, responsibility-aware integration
integration.intro: LogisQ-WES integrates via events and messages, not tight coupling.
integration.steps: PLC emits event → Hub normalizes → PER evaluates → MFC executes
integration.bridge: Data ownership and decision authority remain explicit at every step.

digitalTwin.title: Design-time transparency, not runtime control
digitalTwin.intro: Digital Twin capabilities support design validation and alignment.
digitalTwin.bridge: They do **not** replace execution logic at runtime.

processes.title: Core Warehouse Processes
processes.intro: LogisQ-WES provides specialized execution semantics for the entire warehouse lifecycle.

items.title: Goods Receipt (Inbound Processing)
items.description: Acceptance, identification, inspection, and formal takeover of goods into the system.

items.title: Putaway (Storage Allocation)
items.description: Allocation and execution of storage to the correct bin location using optimized logic.

items.title: Order Release & Prioritization
items.description: Release of orders including prioritization driven by time, customer, or SLA requirements.

items.title: Picking
items.description: Removal of items or handling units for customer, production, or transfer orders.

items.title: Replenishment
items.description: Automated supply movement to picking or production zones to ensure availability.

items.title: Consolidation / Deconsolidation
items.description: Merging or splitting orders, pallets, or loading units for optimal transport and storage.

items.title: Quality Control
items.description: Inspection, verification, and quality assurance of goods before final dispatch.

items.title: Shipping / Goods Issue
items.description: Dispatch preparation, loading, and recording of the goods issue.

items.title: Internal Relocation
items.description: Re-slotting and repositioning to optimize space, paths, or accessibility.

items.title: Inventory Counting & Adjustment
items.description: Permanent or periodic inventory counting including difference clarification.

items.title: Returns Processing
items.description: Processing of returned goods including inspection and re-storage workflows.

items.title: VAS (Value Added Services)
items.description: Kitting, set building, custom packing, labeling, and other value-adding activities before dispatch.

final.text:
LogisQ-WES does not optimize execution by guessing.
**PER** executes what was defined — consistently, transparently, and safely.

contactPage.title: Get in Touch
contactPage.subtitle: Ready to modernize your warehouse? Don't let outdated systems slow you down.
contactPage.highlight: Meet the team that will take control of your operations.

brownfieldPage.title: Brownfield Modernization
brownfieldPage.subtitle: Modernize without bringing operations to a halt.
brownfieldPage.intro: LogisQ-WES allows you to introduce modern execution capabilities into existing facilities, upgrading legacy systems step-by-step.

blocks.b1Desc: Introduce new modules alongside legacy systems.
blocks.b2Desc: The CommunicationHUB acts as a translator between old and new.
blocks.b3Desc: Test new logic on a small scope before full rollout.
blocks.b4Desc: Extend the life of your existing mechanical hardware.

fleetPage.title: Fleet Management
fleetPage.subtitle: Orchestrate mixed fleets from a single source of truth.
fleetPage.intro: LogisQ-WES integrates AGVs, AMRs, and forklifts into the same execution flow as your conveyors and manual stations.

features.f1Desc: Control robots from different manufacturers via VDA 5050 or native APIs.
features.f2Desc: Prevent deadlocks and optimize routing in shared workspaces.

specificationsPage.title: Specification & Features
specificationsPage.subtitle: Technical capabilities of the LogisQ-WES Warehouse Execution System
specificationsPage.metaDescription: Technical specifications and features of LogisQ-WES - the modular warehouse execution system for automated and manual logistics.

specs.title: Concurrent Processes
specs.desc: Simultaneous execution threads for high-throughput operations

specs.title: Event Processing
specs.desc: Real-time event handling for immediate operational response

specs.title: Integration Protocols
specs.desc: Including OPC-UA, REST, MQTT, VDA 5050, and proprietary PLCs

features.title: Workflow-First Execution
features.desc: Processes are defined explicitly and executed deterministically

features.title: Modular Architecture
features.desc: WMS, PER, MFC, and CommunicationHUB as independent modules

features.title: Real-Time Orchestration
features.desc: Coordinates tasks across people, automation, and systems

features.title: Event-Driven Integration
features.desc: Loose coupling via events, not tight API dependencies

features.title: Brownfield Ready
features.desc: Integrates with existing hardware and legacy systems
